summary: The company, formerly IBM's infrastructure services business, has been restructuring multiple no-margin contracts it inherited from the Big Blue to generate higher profits, but at the cost of revenue growth. Businesses have prioritized spending on essential software amid macroeconomic uncertainty spurred by U.S. President Donald Trump's ongoing global trade negotiations.

title: Exclusive-Three Intel senior executives to retire amid manufacturing shake up
summary: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) -Three senior executives in Intel's manufacturing operations are set to retire, Intel told Reuters on Thursday, as new CEO Lip-Bu Tan implements sweeping change to resuscitate the struggling U.S. chipmaker.  Intel told staff on Tuesday that corporate vice presidents in the technology development group, Kaizad Mistry and Ryan Russell, would retire, as would Gary Patton, corporate vice president at its Design Technology Platform organization and a former IBM executive.  Intel also discussed changes to the technology development group, which is responsible for creating manufacturing processes, said two people briefed on the matter.

On the other hand, next quarter’s revenue guidance of $15.72 billion was less impressive, coming in 2.3% below analysts’ estimates. Its non-GAAP profit of $2.80 per share was 5.5% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

title: IBM's software sales disappoint, eclipsing AI mainframe revival
summary: (Reuters) -IBM beat Wall Street estimates for second-quarter revenue and profit on Wednesday, but lower-than-expected sales in its mainstay software segment overshadowed a renewal in demand for the mainframe business spurred by AI upgrades.  "You're seeing the stock pull back, because there's just not a lot of room to miss," said Dan Morgan, senior portfolio manager at Synovus Trust, which holds shares in IBM.  IBM's software segment, which has traditionally been a bright spot, reported sales of $7.39 billion, missing analysts' average estimate of $7.41 billion, according to data compiled by LSEG.

title: US stocks close higher, Treasury yields soften as tariff deadlines, earnings loom
summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -Wall Street stocks advanced on Monday, while Treasury yields softened at the top of a busy week of corporate earnings reports, as tariff negotiations between the U.S. and its trading partners ramped up in the face of a fast-approaching August 1 deadline.  All three major U.S. stock indexes moved higher in opposition to their European counterparts, gold notched a five-week high and the dollar weakened against the yen in the wake of Japan's weekend elections.  "We've had optimism around trade, and it's early days but we’ve had pretty good earnings so far," said Zachary Hill, head of portfolio management at Horizon Investments in Charlotte, North Carolina.

title: Coca-Cola, GM, Alphabet, Tesla: Earnings to watch this week
summary: Asking for a Trend host Josh Lipton breaks down the major earnings reports to keep an eye on this coming week. On Monday, Verizon (VZ), Ryanair (RYAAY), and Domino's (DPZ) will publish earnings reports. On Tuesday, Coca-Cola (KO), Lockheed Martin (LMT), General Motors (GM), RTX (RTX), Sherwin-Williams (SHW), and D.R. Horton (DHI) report results. Coca-Cola will post its second quarter results on Tuesday before the opening bell, just days after President Trump said the company will start to use cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup. GM is also reporting its second quarter results before markets open on Tuesday, as analysts expect numbers to be in line with estimates. On Wednesday, AT&T (T), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL), IBM (IBM), GE Vernova (GEV), Tesla (TSLA), and T-Mobile (TMUS) are releasing earnings. Alphabet's second quarter results will be out after the markets close on Wednesday. CapEx, ad prices, and cloud are all in focus for Alphabet. Tesla's second quarter numbers are also out Wednesday after the closing bell. Analysts expect earnings to be in line with estimates. On Thursday, Honeywell (HON), Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP), Intel (INTC), Union Pacific (UNP), Tractor Supply Company (TSCO), and Deckers (DECK) announce results. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Asking for a Trend here.

title: Business Lookahead: Rate decisions, business activity surveys
summary: STORY: From central bank meetings to reports from some of the "Magnificent Seven," these are the stories to watch in business and finance in the coming week.:: Look Ahead:: Set to pauseThe European Central Bank is set to pause on Thursday after eight consecutive rate cuts halved its policy rate to 2%.It comes as a 30% U.S. tariff threat looms over the euro zone.Policymakers will be reluctant to create the sense that they are reacting to a threat, but they’ll have to reassess their worst case scenario from June, which foresaw a lower tariff level.:: Earnings in earnestMore than one-fifth of S&P 500 companies are expected to report in the coming week.Market heavyweights Alphabet and Tesla are the first of the “Magnificent Seven” to report this period.:: Coca-ColaResults are also due from Coca-Cola, IBM and Phillip Moris International.:: Business timeJuly surveys of business activity across the globe may capture shifts in behavior in both services and manufacturing in response to Trump’s new August 1 tariff deadline.Twenty-two of the world’s 34 largest economies have slowing activity, leaving the services sector to do much of the heavy lifting.In June, services activity in the U.S., euro zone, China and Germany were slower than in December, and well below last June.Among richer nations, only Japan and Britain saw a year-on-year improvement in service-sector activity last month.:: Turkey’s central bankTurkey’s central bank is expected to return to rate cuts on Thursday.That's after the March detention of Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu roiled markets, knocked the lira to a record low, saw stocks trading suspended and prompted the central bank to hike overnight rates to 46%.A Reuters poll showed expectations for a 250-basis point cut, with some predicting as much as 350 bps.Central banks in Hungary and Russia also hold rate meetings in the coming week.
